urn:contentItem:5SW9-WRF1-DY0W-40V5-00000-00Tech Earnings on Tap; Mass Shooting in Toronto; War of Words with Iran; Reading Alphabet; Crude Awakening; Papa John's Adopts Poison Pill; Hawaii's Big Island Calls For Lava Tourism; Star Trek-Inspired Vodka2018-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:34ZLexisNexisTech Earnings on Tap; Mass Shooting in Toronto; War of Words with Iran; Reading Alphabet; Crude Awakening; Papa John's Adopts Poison Pill; Hawaii's Big Island Calls For Lava Tourism; Star Trek-Inspired VodkaLanhamFULL TEXT

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And it's time for MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We send it right over to Dagen McDowell.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning ladies, we'll see you both coming up shortly. Good morning everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, July 23rd, your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Earnings in focus, it will be the busiest week for second quarter reporting season, one-third of the Dow Industrials and the S&P500 set to post results this week. We'll look at the numbers and guidance and what they all say about the state of the United States economy.

Futures are showing this this morning, we have slight losses but, again, even a tweak from the president could change all of that. After the close today we get earnings from Alphabet, the parent of Google. Again, that just kicks off a blockbuster week.

Those markets, those Futures after the major market gauges finish the day on Friday, little change. You had the Dow and S&P were up for the week, but the NASDAQ Composite for the week was slightly lower last week.

In Europe we have declines across the board to tell you about, the biggest loser there being the CAC Quarante in France down about half of one percent. In Asia overnight some mixed action, the Nikkei in Japan the worst performer of the lot down more than one percent.

A tragedy in Toronto, a deadly shooting rampage late last night, a gunman killing at least one, injuring more than a dozen others.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I heard at least 20 shots in intervals, you know, clipping, spent, reloading, clipping, spent. I saw at least four people shot her by the fountain.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is a street where people walk every day, go to the groceries, have dinner, have an ice cream, sit in a square, enjoy their summer and it's absolutely devastating.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We have the latest on the investigation coming up. President Trump takes on Iran, the president issuing a sharp warning in a late night tweet threatening severe consequences if Iran doesn't take a cautious tone with the United States.

And unexpected change at the top for FiatChrysler, the automaker replacing well-known CEO Sergio Marchionne after he stopped for complications from recent surgery. What the change means for the future of the company.

And out of this world vodka, Star Trek fans will be able to get a taste space with alcohol inspired by the Starship Enterprise.

All that and so much more coming up this morning, CFRA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell. PWC Partner Mitch Roschelle. And Maslansky & Partners President Lee Carter. We're going to tee up what is going to be an incredible week. One thing we'd left out in the open is we get second quarter GDP, the first reading on how fast this economy is growing, that comes out on Friday.

We're going to hear from all of these major technology companies and get a sense of what the financial world looks like in the health of the U.S.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Yes. It's going to be a big week for sure. And we're going to finally see what corporate health looks like. Tech sector's going to be very, very strong.

We've got over 22 percent growth for the second quarter from these tech companies, that is a six quarter in a row for over 21 percent earnings growth. You're looking at the S&P500, earnings growth of 20.8 percent based on S&P capital IQ estimates right now.

So things are looking good so far, companies are beating on the bottom line, the top line beat rate at 76 percent has come down over the last week.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BELL: We'd like to see that improve a little bit but the dollar's kind of weighing there.

MCDOWELL: So, we're going to dig into more of that. You teed it up nicely Lindsey Bell, thank you so much. And then the president's approval rating going up, so we're going to talk about that as well, I can't wait for that.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Such a fascinating topic because who would have thought --

MCDOWELL: Well --

CARTER: -- based on everything else (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: -- you know what, the people who believe in his policies are tuning out the noise.

CARTER: That's right. And that's what we talked about, he got a floor and it's not going to move.

MCDOWELL: OK. We're going to talk about that coming up in just a few minutes.

But first our top story this hour, tech earnings on tap, Futures are searching for a little bit of direction his morning, a start of huge week for corporate earnings. Dow Industrial Futures are down 15 points at the moment.

Alphabet, Facebook, Amazon, Twitter, all set to report second quarter results this week with Apple -- with Alphabet leading the way today. The parent of Google reporting after the bell. Lindsey, can you dig into these?

These are the companies that have been driving the performance and I'm going to look up a step that I have on my phone, but how critical will -- just these big name tech companies be?

BELL: It's going to be huge and what's most -- going to be the most important as is every quarter but especially this quarter, we saw what happened with Netflix guidance.

Guidance is going to be key, I don't think there's going to be any dispute that this has been a great quarter. Like what you said on Friday, we're going to get an amazing economic GDP number. But I think that what people want to watch is what's happening with the top line and is guidance improving?

And we have actually seen surprisingly industrial companies raising guidance for the remainder of the year which you would -- a sector that's been impacted by trade.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PARTNER, PWC: This trade in a way as I'm listening to some of those earnings calls, I would have expected using the tariffs as a bit of an excuse. You know, corporate managers often look for something out there, it's a bit of an excuse just to sort of temporary guidance --

BELL: Absolutely.

ROSCHELLE: -- and they're not using tariffs, which is quite surprising. You're also not using the tight labor market as an excuse. So that's been sort of interesting.

BELL: I know. Which is a change in tone from what we've seen previously.

MCDOWELL: But speaking of the industrial earnings, Honeywell's numbers out on Friday were great . That they had higher sales in profit margins across, I think, all four of their -- it's divisions, that was out on Friday.

But in terms of trade impact and the tariffs that have gone into effect on steel and aluminum, the retaliation from major trading partners, Canada, Mexico and even China, we're going to get earnings this week from TRIUM, Harley-Davidson, and Whirlpool.

So, again, you're going to have to decide Mitch whether they're using maybe the trade dispute as an excuse or if it's having a legitimate impact on business here.

ROSCHELLE: And we'll see -- we'll see -- if it's the guidance, you don't know. But if it's impacting second quarter earnings then it's not an excuse, it's reality. So we'll see then.

MCDOWELL: So industrial stocks actually are down two percent year-to-date while the S&P500 is up nearly five percent. And there are some stocks that are in, well, the toilet.

Caterpillar is down 14 -- 13 percent, 3M is down 14 percent year-to-date. And also Alcoa had -- has had a major selloff in recent days.

BELL: Right. Alcoa you saw the tariffs impacting their business with aluminum. They bring a lot of it in from Canada, so they -- they're saying every month they expect a 12 to 14 million dollar hit to the profitability of the company.

This is definitely a huge -- the big question I think when you think about the industrial company is, are they pulling this business forward ahead of the tariffs going into effect? And so that's why the second quarter is significantly better than expected.

The industrial sector has been in the toilet like you said. The fourth worth performing sector of all 11, but the stocks are reacting very, very positively to this news. On average, the companies that have reported so far have moved up two and a half percentage points versus the S&P500 up 1.6. Last quarter, stocks weren't reacting to earnings at all.

MCDOWELL: That's great news. And I was just going to -- what I was pulling up on my phone, it's not -- I'm not ignoring you. I'm not -- I'm not texting -- I'm not texting with my mother.

But if you look at just last week, they were -- of the major technology stocks, there were only two that were lower out, Netflix was -- fell off a cliff --

BELL: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- it was down nine percent because of that miss, partially to blame its own guidance. And then Alphabet was down going into this earnings report, half of one percent last week. But, again, Microsoft is out with earnings, number one Dow stock and is -- hit an all-time high on Friday I believe.

BELL: And that bodes well for Alphabet because they're in the cloud business, to the third largest cloud provider. We want to see tonight how those numbers look.

ROSCHELLE: Right.

MCDOWELL: The economy a big part of republican plans to retain control of the House. Here's what House Major Whip Steve Scalise told Maria on Sunday Morning Futures.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. STEVE SCALISE (R-LA), HOUSE MAJORITY WHIP: The plans to continue focusing on getting the economy moving, seeing this great economic growth and then locking it in. We're going to bring some more bills to cut taxes, we're going to make the tax cuts permanent.

That bill, Chairman Brady and his committee are already working on. We just did a jobs 3.0 bill, a bill to provide more regulatory relief and do some more things that will help create more jobs and rebuild the middle class.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: This comes as a new Wall Street Journal NBC News Poll found that half of registered voters approve of President Trump's handling on the economy. His highest mark on that question in the survey.

And also president's overall approval rating did inch up a little bit. Lee, what do you make of that?

CARTER: So I think it's really, really fascinating to say that the president's job approval rating was the highest it's been after a lot of people said they did not approve of his handling of the meeting with Putin, that was over 68 percent of people, so they did not approve of that.

But the bottom line is this, when you look at Trump's handling of the economy, 50 percent of Americans approve of it, 34 percent don't. People feel that it's in their pocketbooks, they're seeing the markets rise, they're seeing their 401(k) balances go up, they're feeling better more optimistic, they're seeing jobs, more opportunities for themselves.

So, even when these things happen, even when, you know, the president makes comments that makes everybody uncomfortable after he did -- as he did in Helsinki. The more hysterical people get, the more upset, the more that they go after him, the more his face is short up, and the more people go, "You know what though, I'm still feeling better economically."

And that is why people go to the polls. Russia is down there, I think number 16 as far as issues that are most important to the American people right now. And so I think what the democrats need to do, if they want to win this in November is they've got to come up with a message that is going to counter anything that the president's doing in the economy.

And I think that's why we're seeing a rise in the socialist movement because people are saying, "Here are some in it. If we're going to do this it's going to make life better for you. We're going to give you jobs, we're going to give you foreign income, we're going to get healthcare for all."

That's the message that gets people excited whether we want to -- and we can have a debate on that. But just going after the president and saying that he's the worst thing that's ever happen and really getting hysterical about it, that's not going to work for the democrats. And I think if that's the way that they're going to approach November, they're going to have big problems.

MCDOWELL: But, again, it comes down to in terms of this democratic socialist message or whatever you want to call them these days, it comes down to how you're going to pay for it. And that's one thing that does hit people in the pocketbook.

That's by the president's tweets about the Federal Reserve last week, it did resonate with people. Like it or not, I mean we kind of worry about the president interfering in what is so-called independent Federal Reserve but, again, people -- that -- people understand that.

ROSCHELLE: Well what's interesting and sort of to Lee's point, I think at the end of the day, the average voter isn't a creature of the new cycle like the four of us are, OK? They're not really paying attention to a lot of it and they really focus on making ends meet, providing for their family, and if they feel better about that, I think it's going to show up in the polls.

MCDOWELL: And I did want to point out Lee that -- because we were talking about it, the president's overall approval rating did end higher in that poll. It ends up to 45 percent. And, again, buoyed by strong support within his base, within the republican base.

CARTER: That's right. See, that I think as much as there where things that went wrong in Helsinki, there's also things a lot of optimism on the republicans by Kavanaugh and the Supreme Court appointment. I think people are feeling strong support there and I think that is really helping the president right now.

MCDOWELL: And that's what the republicans and particularly the Senate, they're showing resistance to this Tax cuts 2.0 that the House is pushing. Ultimately it falls on the Senate to make sure that Kavanaugh is approved and voted on to the Supreme Court --

CARTER: That's right.

MCDOWELL: -- by the midterm elections. And then what -- we have another Putin visit potentially in the fall, so we'll see how that goes.

CARTER: Rise on that.

MCDOWELL: Yes. We'll see how that goes just in time for the midterm. Coming up, tragedy in Toronto, at least one person dead, more than a dozen hurt after a mass shooting. We have the latest as police investigate the motive behind the brazen attack.

And shifting gears at FiatChrysler, Mike Manley taking over the CEO job as Sergio Marchionne suffers a sudden health crisis, the details next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A mass shooting in Toronto, Cheryl Casone has the details. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Well Dagen, good morning. A frightening scene after a gunman killed at least one person and injured at least 13 others including a young girl.

During the rampage, the suspect later killed at that scene, it happened at the Toronto neighborhood known as Greek Town.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK SAUNDERS, TORONTO POLICE CHIEF: Shortly after 10:00p.m. what happened was the police responded to a 911 call for sounds of gunshots. A young girl is in critical state right now and the other 13 are in the hospital and being treated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well investigators are trying to find a motive and police say they would not rule out terrorism.

Well, stunning news, and a change at the top for FiatChrysler breaking over the weekend, its longtime CEO Sergio Marchionne has been replaced. Marchionne underwent shoulder surgery about three weeks ago but his condition has since worsened according to the company.

Now Mike Manley who runs the Jeep SUV and RAM truck division is the new CEO. Shares of FiatChrysler we should say are lower on this news. Sergio, of course, as stunning force for the company, down three percent in the premarket as you can see.

And then there was a new record set at the box office this weekend, eight of the top ten movies were sequels. And the top spot went to a surprise upset.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: They killed my friend. (INAUDIBLE) in everyone of them and the only disappointment is that I only get to do it once.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well Sony's "The Equalizer 2" starring Denzel Washington brought in $35.8 million. Equalizer narrowly beat another sequel, Universal's "Mama Mia Here We Go Again" which made $34.4 million which beat the original film by the way by about seven million bucks, pretty good.

Taking third, Sony's "Hotel Transylvania III" with $23.3 million. Rounding up top five, "Ant Man and the Wasp" and "Incredibles 2" Dagen. Feel free to have "Mama Mia" stuck in your head for the rest of the morning as I do right at this moment.

MCDOWELL: You know why it beat the original?

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: One word, Cher.

CASONE: Cher. Got you.

MCDOWELL: There you go.

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Just despite her craziness on Twitter, I can't even -- she speaks a language of her own on Twitter. But --

ROSCHELLE: This is a business program, so I'd like to know how much ABBA gets every time there's a -- one of those movies, "Mama Mia" movies.

BELL: Oh yes.

MCDOWELL: Well I think we'll -- we will put the burden on you Mitch Roscelle.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. I'm going to start Googling -- I'm a -- I ask a question, research the results. All right.

CARTER: And theory.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly.

BELL: I saw the show on Broadway and it was absolutely phenomenal.

MCDOWELL: So this is the -- this is the sequel.

BELL: Yes.

MCDOWELL: So if Meryl Streep is still in -- this is the sequel to the original film. So, again, ABBA who would have thought?

Coming up, war of words with Iran, President Trump ramping up the tough talk as sanctions on the country are reinstated next week and after he dumped the Obama Era nuclear deal. The stern threat, next.

And now you can have vodka from the final frontier, find out how you can throwback a cocktail made with just a hint of the extra-terrestrial.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Escalating tensions with Iran, President Trump calling out Iran's president after the leader said U.S. policies toward the country could lead to the "mother of all wars" with Iran.

In a tweet last night the president wrote, "To Iranian President Rouhani, never ever threaten the United States again or you will suffer consequences the likes of which few throughout history have ever suffered before. We are no longer a country that will stand for your demented words of violence and death, be cautious." All caps.

This coming as the Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is calling out Iran's religious leaders and address plans to re-impose economic sanctions.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: The Ayatollahs are in on the act too. Judging by their best, well they seem more concerned with riches than religion. These hypocritical (INAUDIBLE) all kinds of crooked schemes to become some of the wealthiest men on earth while their people suffer.

Right now the United States is undertaking a diplomatic and financial pressure campaign to cut off the funds that the regime uses to enrich itself and support death and destruction.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Joining us the Editorial Director for the Washington Examiner, Hugo Gurdon. Hugo, your take on this?

HUGO GURDON, EDITORIAL DIRECTOR, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: You know, President Trump is reminding the Iranians that things don't go well when those countries threaten the United States.

Your viewers probably remember that Saddam Hussein promised the mother of all battles against the United States but he was crying uncle after three weeks o the first Gulf War and he was dead after the second.

What you're really hearing is the fact that the Iranians are feeling the strain of the end of the deal that President Obama put in place. The United States, Israel, and some Arab countries are really putting pressure on Iran to undermine it throughout the region and the peeps have started to squeak.

MCDOWELL: Do you think that we get a new deal because, again, we're -- new sanctions will go into place, I think it starts next month.

There's the issue about Europe, but partly few American companies really stepped up to begin doing business in a significant way in Iran after that nuclear deal from President Obama because it was not ratified as a treaty and they assumed that the next president because it could be a republican would pull out of it and sure enough, that's what happened.

GURDON: Right. Well American companies did not but the European countries certainly have. But, you know, the European countries going to have to make the calculation, do they want to do business with the Iranian economy or do they want to do business with the much, much bigger American economy? It's hardly a choice at all.

They are going to have to adjust, they're going to have to start scaling back and ending business and, of course, there are the oil -- there's the question of oil exports. It's that that could mean as much as $1 trillion of losses, loss revenue to the Iranians over the course of the next 10 years.

This is really, really serious problems for the Iranians that the Mullahs have losing support from the country, the country is fed up with their theocracy. And as I say, you know, the allies, the United States, Israel, and countries like Saudi Arabia are increasing pressure to try and undermine the Iranian Regime.

ROSCHELLE: Hugo, Mitch Roschelle. And Dagen made reference to it in terms of whether or not there's a new deal. If there was some sort of new deal, what would the foundation of that deal be? Obviously be much different than the deal in the past but is there sort of a rubric or a framework for what a deal would look like?

GURDON: It seems to me that -- I mean, this obviously as to some extent a speculation at this point. It doesn't seem to me that there's a deal that can be done with the Iranians, you know, in the way that the -- that Obama Administration did.

I mean, the last thing that this administration wants to do is to cement the Iranian Regime in place. I don't know that there's any deal that could be done which was acceptable to this country and acceptable to Iran. I mean, that's something we're going to have to read about and see.

MCDOWELL: I was going to -- just to clarify Hugo, I said the first sanctions are set to be -- take place next month, it's actually on August the 4th. So it's coming up shortly, followed by the measures that will target Iranian oil, that begins to happen on November 4th.

That's why it's so critical that the United States has a growing oil supply that we're increasingly energy independent or heading toward that.

GURDON: Right.

MCDOWELL: We're the biggest exporter in the world of refine petroleum product and that --

GURDON: Exactly.

MCDOWELL: -- gives us an incredible amount of leverage over someone like Russia and its partner in crime Iran.

GURDON: Exactly. So, the United States became the biggest energy producer. I think more than a year ago it's now the biggest oil producer as well, it's overtaking Saudi Arabia.

This gives it leverage all over the world. For example, President Trump in Europe just a week or so ago pressing Germany on the gas pipeline from Russia, putting pressure on them to buy energy from the United States.

The United States has a much greater ability than it has ever had to control the price of oil and that's the way it can really squeeze the Iranians.

BELL: But then there was also the report that we were going to give some of our allies in Europe a pass on purchasing oil from Iran, is that still on the table because I've heard stories both ways?

GURDON: Yes. You know, I've hears stories both ways too. You know, there's also -- it's also being said that, "No, the November deadline is a deadline and the Europeans are going to have to fall into line."

And the closer we get to that deadline the more likely it is that the Europeans are going to have to scramble to get themselves in position. They don't want to lose business, they don't want to any sanctions that prevent their access to the American market. The Iranian market is much, much smaller.

MCDOWELL: And all of this surely will be discussed with Jean-Claude Juncker, the President of the European Commission who's visiting the White House on Wednesday of this week because in recent months the -- Europe has been talking about exploring activating accounts for the Iranian Central Bank to basically keep this agreement alive. So there's much to discuss in terms of Iran in Europe.

GURDON: Right.

MCDOWELL: Hugo, thank you for being here. It's great to see you as always.

GURDON: Thanks so much.

MCDOWELL: Hugo Gurdon. Coming up, pizza fight, the board of Papa John's is going to extremes to prevent the company's founder from gaining controlling interest after stepping down for using a racial epitaph. We've got the details on the so-called poison pill.

And turning nature's wrath into a tourist destination, Hawaii's plan to help boost tourism by using the same lava that's damaging the industry.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Good morning, I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, July 23rd, your top stories at 6:30 a.m. Eastern. Earning season in full swing, one-third of the Dow and S&P 500 later to post results, this week.

Checking market action this morning, we have Futures are slightly lower across the board, but much news is coming down the pipeline to move those markets, 19-point loss on Dow Futures, right now. On Friday, all three major market gauges finished the day, little change. It was still an up week for the Dow and S&P.

In Europe, we have declines across the board, in England, France and Germany, stocks selling off in just a bit. The biggest loser is the CAC Quarante in France, down half of one percent. In Asia overnight, markets closing mixed. The Nikkei in Japan and the KOSPI in South Korea, both lower.

A board room battle heating up. Why Papa John's board members are adopting a poison pill to stop its founder from gaining controlling stake in the pizza chain. That's ahead.

Plus, Hawaii is working to bring business back after volcanic eruptions displaced residents. How the state could start a lava tourism business, later this hour. And a new alcohol is taking inspiration from Star Trek.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Captain Scott is unaware of the existence of Synthehol.

CAPTAIN SCOTT: Synthehol?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, sir. It is an alcohol substitute, now being served aboard star ships. It simulates the appearance, taste and smell of alcohol, but the intoxicating effects can be easily dismissed.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Details of new liquor that contains vodka from space and also an award to the producer who located that clip from Star Trek generation. But to our top story this half hour, technology in focus, among the big names reporting earnings today, Google's parent company, Alphabet, less than a week after the company was hit with a record five billion-dollar fine by the E.U.

Our next guest is, there's opportunity here, joining me now is Alfred Eskandar, CEO of Salt Financial, Alfred, good to see you.

ALFRED ESKANDAR, CEO, SALT FINANCIAL: Good morning, good to be here.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you. What are you expecting from Alphabet today?

ESKANDAR: We're pretty excited about Google's earnings today. And we think

MCDOWELL: Yes, just call (INAUDIBLE)

ESKANDAR: We think it has shown a lot more life lately. It has gone from what we viewed as a very calm stock only rising about 1.1 percent more than the S&P for the first few months to now, actually showing a whole lot more sensitivity and what we really look for are stocks and sectors that are sensitive to the overall market because we think that's where investors can get an edge.

BELL: Well, volatility, really, when we enter this year, it's just been a theme, it's been returned to the market and I think a lot of individual investors have had a hard time dealing with that.

But the good news about that is it resulted in a decoupling of individual securities from the actual overall market, how do you take advantage of that and is tech the biggest place that you can take advantage of it?

ESKANDAR: Well, tech has really been the big story all year. In fact, if you look at its performance, it's up around 50 percent, year to date, versus, what, five percent for the S&P, so -- but if you're going to have a broader market rally, other sectors need to participate as well.

Volatility as you mentioned, has spiked up this year. Certainly, we all remember February. But if you look at last year, we all kind of fell asleep. Volatility was incredibly low. The market was tremendously resilient and just showed no sign of slowing down or going down.

This year, volatility has returned a little bit more to normal, I believe (INAUDIBLE) around 12, 13 right now. Normally, it's actually around 17. So, we are still somewhat calm.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

So yes, we call this a trade war, but really this is about a remedy for thievery. It has trade implications, of course, but we've got to do this, Dagen -- because the Chinese take hundreds of billions of dollars of U.S. IP a year. This is just unsustainable.

MCDOWELL: Well then, why didn't we take the tack that was pushed by Peter Navarro in terms of cracking down on Chinese companies buying entities here in the United States and then the technology exports into China? CHANG: Because we're Americans and we are so oblivious and have been for a very long time. You know, you started to see a change in Washington. CHANG: Well, it certainly does, you know. And President Trump has hinted about the pain. But clearly, you cannot have decades of really bad trade policy and policies on IP theft and not expect that the U.S. isn't going to suffer at all.

CARTER: So there's a lot of people out there who are saying this is a game of chicken. And that, ultimately, that the Chinese are going to have to give something up here. How long do you think it's going to take that we're going to be feeling this pain until there's some movement?

CHANG: Yes. I don't think we have to worry about the debt. The one thing, you know, if President Trump really wants to hurt the Chinese economy, he just allows Chairman Powell to raise rates. Because what you're seeing right now is U.S. interest rate increases are affecting the Chinese economy.

ROSCHELLE: Just from a capital markets perspective, we've seen money flowing out of Chinese equity markets. It's just sort of thinking about it, that President Trump will actually go forward with the $200 billion and more beyond that. SPICER: Well, but, again, I don't -- part of what we don't know is what exactly was said, the context it was said, and what Trump did or did not respond. I think the White House has made it very clear that the idea that Russia would interrogate any United States citizen, never mind the former ambassador, is fairly laughable.

And I think it's good that they clarified these kinds of things because it's not -- I mean, the idea that a former government official would be interrogated by any country, never mind Russia in Putin, is something that we should be very clear about what our nation's position is.

MCDOWELL: If Putin -- assuming that Putin does come to the United States right before the midterm elections and there was a second summit on U.S. soil, be sure that there will be people in that tete-a-tete.

SPICER: Well, I think the President is seeing the reaction that he saw walking out of that summit. I think they're going to come in to any kind of future summit with their A game.

CARTER: Do you think that --

MCDOWELL: So, you are saying that wasn't the President's A game?

SPICER: No, I think that they -- after meeting with Kim, I think they looked at the model and they were -- there was largely a lot of praise coming from that, how the President had handled that meeting, how the reaction had been in terms of him engaging with Kim, talking about denuclearization in the peninsula.

And I think that this Helsinki summit seemed to follow a very similar pattern. I don't think that they fully appreciated the reaction that Putin would get, versus Kim.

CARTER: I also think the President didn't help himself with some of the statements that he made, following, right? Where he was almost -- seemed like he was (INAUDIBLE) more with Russia than --

SPICER: Sure. And I think it's a good thing that they went out and clarified.

CARTER: Now, how do you think -- what do you think about his clarification? Do you think that was enough? Do you think people buy it?

SPICER: You know, so far, it seems like they do, I think it's important. I mean, look, he has been -- it's good that he clarified it. And, you know, I -- talk -- there is an intensity to this White House of how they cover it -- how they cover this president unlike ever before.

MCDOWELL: The (INAUDIBLE) and the media.

SPICER: The media. And that's why I wrote a book that literally goes through a lot of these big moments and how -- thank you, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I'm holding - I was going to ask you about this.

SPICER: OK. What I mean, I think that there is a level of intensity in scrutiny that in past administrations, they haven't had to face.

MCDOWELL: True. But it's called the briefing politics, the press and the President. I would say, you put the words, the press, on the front cover of a book, that doesn't really help sales, my friend.

SPICER: Well, I will --

MCDOWELL: People hate the --

SPICER: But I think part of what people want to know is, what is it really like inside? And that's the thing. You see one thing on television. You get to see us sitting here at the table. What's going on behind-the- scenes?

And part of the reason that I wrote the book is that the press gets to have their say. They get to put in paper, or put on television what they want you to see, what they want you to read. What I wanted to do is take readers behind-the-scenes and say, this is what's actually happening when - - that you don't see.

MCDOWELL: But -- is it safe to say that this is a President, this is a man, the leader of the country who if you are trying to craft a message, you can't control the message, because he is going to say what he wants to say, and you are more crisis response or just a respond --

SPICER: I was going to say -- I wouldn't say no, because -- I mean, right, I think you are clearly in response, he is the leader.

And that is a very different role than I normally played many -- most press people where your job is to craft and execute a message and a plan. This president leads the way in every one of those fronts.

MCDOWELL: There hasn't been any lasting fallout for the President or even the White House. I would argue for anything that on Twitter. And even --

SPICER: No, in fact, I wouldn't. But that's probably why one of the reasons he won. I mean, he has been -- and I write about all of these instances were any other political candidate would have been left for dead. I mean, I guarantee you, if a candidate for office went to Lee and said, poll what I just did.

It would come back and say, you're dead. Get out of the race. And what this President, every time, not only picked himself up, but in most cases, came up stronger.

CARTER: And it's part of -- I mean, it is part of who he is, right? I think people wanted somebody who is going to go down, shape things up and do things differently than it's ever been before. And so the fact that he does this and continues to do it, I think, just reinforces that message.

MCDOWELL: I want to get to Jim Comey, yes, Jim Comey, the midterm elections, three months away, Former FBI Director, Comey, issuing a warning to Democrats.

He tweeted this, yesterday, Democrats, please, please don't lose your minds and rush to the socialist left. This president and his Republican Party are counting on you to do exactly that. America's great middle wants sensible, balanced, ethical leadership.

But where is the sensible balanced ethical candidate who's running for the Democrat?

SPICER: Well, his tweet's a little too late. I mean, that run to the left, already happened. So, he's a little late on his tweet. I mean, that's the problem. They are now having a -- they're tripping over themselves, to go further and further to the left.

They are not progressives. I mean, they are now like Bernie Sanders, was a socialist running for president and was -- at one point, viewed as the extreme. He's now become the mainstream of the Democratic Party, and you have to go further and further to the left, to get traction.

CARTER: You know, I just wonder, though, I can't -- I look at all of this and I think I don't necessarily believe that it's a whole of the Democrats that are going left. I think that it's a socialists, the far left, it's the only part of the party that has a message that resonates to people because they are talking about things that matter most.

MCDOWELL: They're lying to the American people.

CARTER: Whether or not --

MCDOWELL: I know that they're absolutely lying.

CARTER: They're saying something besides resist.

SPICER: To your point, I mean, you can talk about all of these things at some point. They never tell you about the price tag. They never talk about the economic consequences that these policies would have on our economy.

Walking around and telling everyone that everything is going to be free, is a great message. But the reality is, it's unsustainable, and it is not something that is a direction in our country that we have been against for a long time. We have been against socialism and against a lot of this stuff.

And now, we're talking about -- in the other day, they talked about the minimum income -- you know, were people will be given a -- like, that's insane. The idea we should be talking about is how do we create an economy that allows people to have the opportunities that they need, how do we provide a social safety net.

But the idea that we're talking about guaranteeing everybody all of this free stuff, is unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: Real quick, in your book, you don't believe, as the President suggested that most media is the enemy of the state.

SPICER: No. I wrote about it. I actually write that there are a lot of good reporters, and that we need in a democracy a robust and active press corps, that's essential to our democracy. But what we need to do is know where the line is. Call out bad reporters and bad stories and also praise good reports and good stories.

And it is not about being tough that reporters should be in pursuit of the truth. They should write tough, tough stories.

MCDOWELL: Right.

SPICER: But they should be called out when they are wrong.

MCDOWELL: Yes. And cut out the rehearsed hysteria, right, the rehearsed sneering. Coming up, legend in the auto industry, stepping down. The surprise leadership shake-up after FiatChrysler CEO resigned. Plus, earning season in full swing, Stuart Varney weighs in, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: A busy week in the world of Wall Street. No, America! Tech -- big tech companies: Alphabet, that's parent of Google, Facebook, reporting earnings this week. Also, we get the first reading on how fast the economy was growing during the second quarter. Everybody is watching it, especially, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney. I love it when you talk earnings and economic numbers because I know that that's --

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: No, you don't. You don't. You hate it.

MCDOWELL: Yes, I do. Actually, I love it because --

VARNEY: I don't know what I'm talking about when it comes to earnings --

MCDOWELL: That's not true. Again, who held onto his Microsoft stock? You. What stock hit an all-time high on Friday? Microsoft. There you go.

VARNEY: I had nothing to do with earnings per share. I couldn't tell you. Or, QE3 or anything else, and believe me, it didn't. Look, I think this is a pivotal week. The stuff going on this week which would make an enormous difference to your money. As you said, Dagen, first of all, you got the earnings from big tech, it's a big week for big tech. Here they come, we're going to find out how much money they've made and how much they expect to make in the future. That will have a significant impact on those stocks, big tech stocks, which have been leading this market for at least a couple of years. Then, we've got the GDP numbers, that's Friday morning, 8:30 Eastern Time. I know you will be covering it and so will we. I'm expecting around four percent growth per year, annualized growth, four percent.

Now, that would be a blockbuster news item because we've never achieved that rate of growth in the last four -- I think it's been four years since we had a four percent quarter. And then, don't forget, Wednesday, we have the Europeans coming over here, top-level delegation coming over to the White House. They're talking trade. There's the possibility of a breakthrough right there. Either that or a breakdown, one of the two, and that again makes this a very pivotal week. So, I'm glad everybody is tuning in, it's worthwhile.

MCDOWELL: What if we get -- and so much -- I've talked till I'm blue in the face about these potential tariffs on automobile imports and how that would hurt U.S. carmakers and any carmaker abroad or here at home, so many of the foreign automakers have plants here, produce most of the cars that they sell here, in fact. But Stuart, what if we do get a breakthrough, what if we do have, hey, we're just going to get rid of all of the auto tariffs between Europe and the United States? We're safe in the next three years. What if that happens, it would be incredible?

VARNEY: Huge for the markets.

MCDOWELL: Right.

VARNEY: I think the summer rally has been held back by all those negative trade headlines. It's not being pushed down so much as held back I would say. But if you get a breakthrough Wednesday, and they come out with at least a lessening of the tension, an agreement in some form or other to just maybe get rid of some tariffs, that I think would be absolutely huge, that would really set the stage for a big rally.

MCDOWELL: I think about this every morning when I get up. That is the danger of always being negative and --

VARNEY: Wait a minute, wait a minute. The first thing you think of when you wake up in the morning, is, oh, the Europeans are coming to a trade deal. I don't believe it, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, being positive and making sure that you don't look at everything through a negative lens because again, then you miss all the good stuff.

VARNEY: That's the whole point about the Trump presidency, isn't it? Think positive. He's winning, the economy is expanding, we've got prosperity coming at us. You know, think positive, that's why the market is up so much.

MCDOWELL: And even with some mean tweets, that's why his approval ratings are up, too. Stuart, great to see you.

VARNEY: True. Thanks, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, he starts in 10 minutes every day, 9:00 a.m. to noon. Coming up, a phone booth worthy of Superman. Details on the new office cubicle that will cost you over $8,000, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The death toll rising in last night's mass shooting in Toronto. Cheryl Casone has the details. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Dagen, we just got an update from police. A second victim has died from the rampage, a gunman shot 14 people including a young girl in Toronto. The 29-year-old suspect's body was later found at the scene, but it's not clear at this point whether the man actually killed himself or he was shot by police. All of this happened in the Toronto neighborhood known as Greektown.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I would say I heard at least 20 shots in intervals. You know, clippings spent, reloading, clipping spent, reloading, clipping spent, that's what I heard.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, investigators are trying to find a motive. Police say they would not rule out, at this point, terrorism.

Well, tragedy in Maryland overnight after a firefighter died while battling a massive seven alarm blaze. The unidentified firefighter, a 13-year veteran fell through the floor. Three people who were inside the house were able to get out, though, in time. The cause of the fire under investigation, but lightning could be the cause.

Well, some stunning news over the weekend at a change at the top for FiatChrysler. Long-time CEO Sergio Marchionne has been replaced. Marchionne underwent shoulder surgery three weeks ago but in those three weeks, his condition has somehow worsened. We're looking for more details. Now, Mike Manley, who runs the Jeep, SUV, and Ram truck division is the new CEO. While the stock is something to watch today, shares are actually lower in the premarket, it's down more than three percent right now. Again, stunning news over the weekend for this company.

Well, a Superman solution for workers who want more privacy, for the first time in 80 years, the Superman cubicle booth is available for purchase. It fits two people inside -- if that makes sense -- it comes with modern necessities like USB outlets and an Ethernet connection, LED lights. You're going to have to make more money than Clark Kent, though, it's actually running about $8500 per booth. And by the way, in the description it doesn't mention to actually having a phone. I don't think people use those anymore, all right.

And then, finally, there is this, we've been watching this clip over and over again this morning on the show. It appears to show a grown man stealing a foul ball from a child. Well, the Chicago Cubs saw the situation play out in real-time. They ended up giving the young boy an autographed baseball instead. But it turns out the man that everybody is criticizing had helped that boy get a foul ball earlier in the game. You can see him holding a game-used baseball next to his new autographed one, obviously. Yes. So, maybe the guy in the clip isn't as mean as we all think, and we're all beating up on him this morning. So, I wanted to, you know, give you some new details on this developing story in baseball. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Glad I didn't call him a lot of mean -- maybe.

CASONE: Yes, I think he's -- I think he's a little on a defensive.

MCDOWELL: The child deserves all the foul balls. How about that, though?

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, some final thoughts from our all-stars. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Lindsey Bell, Lee Carter, quick final thoughts. Five seconds.

SPICER: I'm glad to be here to kick off the briefing. Thanks for having me.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, take it away, Sir.

VARNEY: I'm surprised at Sean Spicer. I thought he got more to him than that one. He had at least five seconds to spare there.

(LAUGHTER)

SPICER: I yield it to you, Stuart.

VARNEY: Well, you're a good man.

END

urn:contentItem:5SW9-WRF1-DY0W-40RY-00000-00Tech Earnings on Tap; Mass Shooting in Toronto; War of Words with Iran; Reading Alphabet; Crude Awakening; Papa John's Adopts Poison Pill; Hawaii's Big Island Calls For Lava Tourism; Star Trek-Inspired Vodka2018-07-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:29:34ZLexisNexisTech Earnings on Tap; Mass Shooting in Toronto; War of Words with Iran; Reading Alphabet; Crude Awakening; Papa John's Adopts Poison Pill; Hawaii's Big Island Calls For Lava Tourism; Star Trek-Inspired VodkaLanhamFULL TEXT

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And it's time for MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We send it right over to Dagen McDowell.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning ladies, we'll see you both coming up shortly. Good morning everybody, I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, July 23rd, your top stories at 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Earnings in focus, it will be the busiest week for second quarter reporting season, one-third of the Dow Industrials and the S&P500 set to post results this week. We'll look at the numbers and guidance and what they all say about the state of the United States economy.

Futures are showing this this morning, we have slight losses but, again, even a tweak from the president could change all of that. After the close today we get earnings from Alphabet, the parent of Google. Again, that just kicks off a blockbuster week.

Those markets, those Futures after the major market gauges finish the day on Friday, little change. You had the Dow and S&P were up for the week, but the NASDAQ Composite for the week was slightly lower last week.

In Europe we have declines across the board to tell you about, the biggest loser there being the CAC Quarante in France down about half of one percent. In Asia overnight some mixed action, the Nikkei in Japan the worst performer of the lot down more than one percent.

A tragedy in Toronto, a deadly shooting rampage late last night, a gunman killing at least one, injuring more than a dozen others.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I heard at least 20 shots in intervals, you know, clipping, spent, reloading, clipping, spent. I saw at least four people shot her by the fountain.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is a street where people walk every day, go to the groceries, have dinner, have an ice cream, sit in a square, enjoy their summer and it's absolutely devastating.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: We have the latest on the investigation coming up. President Trump takes on Iran, the president issuing a sharp warning in a late night tweet threatening severe consequences if Iran doesn't take a cautious tone with the United States.

And unexpected change at the top for FiatChrysler, the automaker replacing well-known CEO Sergio Marchionne after he stopped for complications from recent surgery. What the change means for the future of the company.

And out of this world vodka, Star Trek fans will be able to get a taste space with alcohol inspired by the Starship Enterprise.

All that and so much more coming up this morning, CFRA Investment Strategist Lindsey Bell. PWC Partner Mitch Roschelle. And Maslansky & Partners President Lee Carter. We're going to tee up what is going to be an incredible week. One thing we'd left out in the open is we get second quarter GDP, the first reading on how fast this economy is growing, that comes out on Friday.

We're going to hear from all of these major technology companies and get a sense of what the financial world looks like in the health of the U.S.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Yes. It's going to be a big week for sure. And we're going to finally see what corporate health looks like. Tech sector's going to be very, very strong.

We've got over 22 percent growth for the second quarter from these tech companies, that is a six quarter in a row for over 21 percent earnings growth. You're looking at the S&P500, earnings growth of 20.8 percent based on S&P capital IQ estimates right now.

So things are looking good so far, companies are beating on the bottom line, the top line beat rate at 76 percent has come down over the last week.

MCDOWELL: Uh-hmm.

BELL: We'd like to see that improve a little bit but the dollar's kind of weighing there.

MCDOWELL: So, we're going to dig into more of that. You teed it up nicely Lindsey Bell, thank you so much. And then the president's approval rating going up, so we're going to talk about that as well, I can't wait for that.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Such a fascinating topic because who would have thought --

MCDOWELL: Well --

CARTER: -- based on everything else (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: -- you know what, the people who believe in his policies are tuning out the noise.

CARTER: That's right. And that's what we talked about, he got a floor and it's not going to move.

MCDOWELL: OK. We're going to talk about that coming up in just a few minutes.

But first our top story this hour, tech earnings on tap, Futures are searching for a little bit of direction his morning, a start of huge week for corporate earnings. Dow Industrial Futures are down 15 points at the moment.

Alphabet, Facebook, Amazon, Twitter, all set to report second quarter results this week with Apple -- with Alphabet leading the way today. The parent of Google reporting after the bell. Lindsey, can you dig into these?

These are the companies that have been driving the performance and I'm going to look up a step that I have on my phone, but how critical will -- just these big name tech companies be?

BELL: It's going to be huge and what's most -- going to be the most important as is every quarter but especially this quarter, we saw what happened with Netflix guidance.

Guidance is going to be key, I don't think there's going to be any dispute that this has been a great quarter. Like what you said on Friday, we're going to get an amazing economic GDP number. But I think that what people want to watch is what's happening with the top line and is guidance improving?

And we have actually seen surprisingly industrial companies raising guidance for the remainder of the year which you would -- a sector that's been impacted by trade.

Joining me now -- Gordon Chang, author of "The Coming Collapse of China". Gordon -- this even follows President Trump's threats to impose tariffs on all $500 billion worth of Chinese imports into this country every year. So we only import -- or export to them about $130 billion or something, and we take from them $505.5 billion last year. It's going to be more this year because we've got a robust economy.

You know, a lot of people say well, you know, the Chinese can retaliate against U.S. companies in China, but Chinese officials don't want that to happen because they're worried about the effect on the Europeans and others who are investing in China. And they think that that could really boomerang on China and hurt Beijing much more than it hurts us.

MCDOWELL: Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin was -- he amplified President Trump's trade threats in Argentina over the weekend at that G-20 meeting of finance ministers. The Secretary said this, quote, "That he wouldn't minimize the chance of the U.S. imposing tariffs on all -- its half a trillion dollars with Chinese goods that we import into the United States, but he still promises a light at the end of the tunnel.

So listen to this, and I want to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MNUCHIN: President Trump is determined to have free and fair and more balanced trade, and we just want to make sure American companies and American workers are treated fairly. And, yes, I do see a light at the end of the tunnel.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: How do you think this plays out? Do you think that it doesn't get to the point where we do slap tariffs on all imports coming in from China?

CHANG: You know, that's a real possibility. You know, we've got remember that this is for the theft of U.S. intellectual property and its forced taking. These are imposed under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 after that investigation into China's thievery.

So yes, we call this a trade war, but really this is about a remedy for thievery. It has trade implications, of course, but we've got to do this, Dagen -- because the Chinese take hundreds of billions of dollars of U.S. IP a year. This is just unsustainable.

MCDOWELL: Well then, why didn't we take the tack that was pushed by Peter Navarro in terms of cracking down on Chinese companies buying entities here in the United States and then the technology exports into China? Instead, we kind of took a little bit of a lighter touch with the increased CFIUS restrictions or committee on foreign investment in the U.S.

That was more what Secretary Mnuchin wanted, that's what Congress is moving to do. They actually came out of conference last week with how that would be applied. So they basically strengthened CFIUS. So why didn't we do more? Why didn't we take a harder approach on that note then?

CHANG: Because we're Americans and we are so oblivious and have been for a very long time. You know, you started to see a change in Washington. It started in the last year of the Obama administration when the President used CFIUS to block a Chinese deal. And then President Trump has blocked two or three acquisitions under CFIUS.

So this is going to be something we're going to see much, much more of. And you know, yes, people don't like tariffs, but now we're starting to think about the alternatives. And of course it's investment bans but also it could end up sort of being like an import ban. If we're starting to look at goods that have been benefiting from China's IP thievery -- there's all sorts of things that the administration can start to look at.

MCDOWELL: But does this administration need to start talking about how this is going to play out in the U.S. economy? More specifically say, hey, half a trillion dollars worth of imports -- everybody in this country, if you buy anything made in China, you're going to pay more for it. Hey, farmers, you've got 2.5 billion pounds of meat that's now piling up as exports slow to these nations. You have soybean farmers that are getting hit.

There is going to be pain, and it could be widespread, but does this administration need to be really frank with the American people about this?

CHANG: Well, it certainly does, you know. And President Trump has hinted about the pain. But clearly, you cannot have decades of really bad trade policy and policies on IP theft and not expect that the U.S. isn't going to suffer at all.

We are going to suffer, but we actually have to do this because of the scale of China's predation.

CARTER: So there's a lot of people out there who are saying this is a game of chicken. And that, ultimately, that the Chinese are going to have to give something up here. How long do you think it's going to take that we're going to be feeling this pain until there's some movement?

CHANG: You know, we could be in a decades-long struggle with China. You know, when the Treasury Secretary talks about having equal access to the Chinese market -- that's just ridiculous. The Chinese system is designed to prevent access of foreigners into China. And under Xi Jinping, the current Chinese ruler, it's become less, you know -- less open than it was before.

So, you know, this is going to be a long-term struggle. So we can be in this for a very, very, very long time.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Well, China's already devaluing their currency. They're releasing reserves from the banks. They're preparing. And they must be feeling the pain right now already from these early moves on trade. What brings them to the table?

CHANG: Well, I think that when Xi Jinping realizes that there's no more Chinese economy left, that's really when you get to the point. Now look --

MCDOWELL: We have that power? Because again, if we want to take more power away from --

CHANG: It's easy.

MCDOWELL: -- but if we want to take more power away from China then we stop running $1 trillion annual budget deficits, which is where we're headed in the 2019 fiscal that we stop spending so much money and we don't have to lean on China so much to buy our debt because we're not -- because we can try to control spending.

CHANG: Yes. I don't think we have to worry about the debt. The one thing, you know, if President Trump really wants to hurt the Chinese economy, he just allows Chairman Powell to raise rates. Because what you're seeing right now is U.S. interest rate increases are affecting the Chinese economy.

Money is coming out. And, you know, you go back to this whole thing about the currency -- I don't think China is actually devaluing its currency. The renminbi is declining. It's tumbling and had its worst month ever last year against the dollar -- I mean last month.

But the point right now is that the Chinese people are not expressing confidence in their own currency. And I think Beijing is trying to prevent the fall rather than encourage it.

You know, down the road, you know, I could see Beijing changing tack and forcefully driving down the renminbi to help exporters. But they're not doing that now because they're so worried about currency outflow which almost killed the economy in 2015 and 2016.

ROSCHELLE: Just from a capital markets perspective, we've seen money flowing out of Chinese equity markets. And does their administration realize that their economy's starting to get shaky?

CHANG: Yes, I think that the Chinese do understand that. You have academics in China starting to say look, we cannot sustain a long-term struggle with the United States. And right now you're starting to see real signs of stress in the Chinese economy whether you're talking about the tumbling stock markets, you know, the currency that looks like it's in the early stages of collapse, all of the debt defaults. You know, private companies -- the problems with the peer-to-peer lenders, it just goes on and on -- Mitch.

All the problems -- I don't know if Xi Jinping has any answer to this except to try to take on more debt, and Chinese people are starting to look at this and say, no, this doesn't work.

ROSCHELLE: But if they continue to take on more debt there, do they have the wallet to buy our debt? Because that could drive our interest rates even higher if there's no bid coming from China for U.S. Treasuries.

CHANG: Yes. Well, you know, China's going to have to sell dollars to support their currency. They've been doing that up to now over the last several months. They're going to have to do more of that just because of their own internal problems.

So, you know, China's going to do what it's going to have to do because their economy's at the point where, you know, anything could -- if it goes wrong -- could trigger those crises of confidence that we saw three years ago.

MCDOWELL: If we're getting tough on China, why didn't we stick by that ban on ZTE in this country? It appears that the sanctions that were put back in this defense bill were stripped out again.

CHANG: Yes. You know, amen to that -- you know, we should not have given them relief. But administration officials don't talk to me, but my guess is this Wednesday there is the deadline on Qualcomm's deal to buy NXP, the semiconductor company. That deal will be held up if China does not give approval.

My guess, Dagen -- and this is just pure speculation is that the administration gave relief to ZTE so that Qualcomm will get that approval for the acquisition. I don't know, but it makes a lot of sense to me that you could have a tit for tat sort of we'll do something for you, you do something for us.

MCDOWELL: So we've got $34 billion in Chinese imports right now that have tariffs on them that they've retaliated dollar for dollar, if you will; another $16 billion coming, an additional $200 billion that's being studied.

CHANG: Right.

MCDOWELL: Do you think that the United States puts a tariff on every dollar worth of imports into this country, more than half a trillion? Do you think that happens?

CHANG: I think we get up to maybe $400 billion is just my guess, you know. And this is nothing that I know. It's just sort of thinking about it, that President Trump will actually go forward with the $200 billion and more beyond that. I don't think we get to the whole $505.5 billion but, you know, we're going to get very, very close.

MCDOWELL: And there's really no way to truly know how China retaliates, isn't it?

CHANG: Yes. Xi Jinping is a tough guy. I mean Larry Kudlow said at that conference a couple of days ago. Look, you know, the Chinese trade officials they want to deal with us, but Xi Jinping is saying no.

So this has become very, very political. They're heading into their August conference, the Communist Party senior officials at Beidaihe. They're going to be talking about this. This is the number one topic on their agenda because Xi Jinping is in trouble politically because he now owns this crisis.

MCDOWELL: How quickly does this show up when people go to a store and want to buy something? They can't find it or they have to pay a lot more for it?

CHANG: I don't think there's a problem because, you know, China is no longer the low cost producer. Companies can shift --

MCDOWELL: Good point.

CHANG: -- production very, very quickly. The only company that can't shift production on a dime is Apple because they're stuck with Foxconn. Foxconn is in Shenzhen and other locations in China. Apple can really get hurt because they're going to be the number one target that the Chinese officials are going to look at.

Yes, they might like Tim Cook today, but tomorrow they see that he's the weak point in the U.S. economy.

CHANG: Thanks.

Here they come, we're going to find out how much money they've made and how much they expect to make in the future. That will have a significant impact on those stocks, big tech stocks, which have been leading this market for at least a couple of years. Then, we've got the GDP numbers, that's Friday morning, 8:30 Eastern Time. I know you will be covering it and so will we. I'm expecting around four percent growth per year, annualized growth, four percent.

Now, that would be a blockbuster news item because we've never achieved that rate of growth in the last four -- I think it's been four years since we had a four percent quarter. And then, don't forget, Wednesday, we have the Europeans coming over here, top-level delegation coming over to the White House. They're talking trade. There's the possibility of a breakthrough right there. Either that or a breakdown, one of the two, and that again makes this a very pivotal week. So, I'm glad everybody is tuning in, it's worthwhile.

MCDOWELL: What if we get -- and so much -- I've talked till I'm blue in the face about these potential tariffs on automobile imports and how that would hurt U.S. carmakers and any carmaker abroad or here at home, so many of the foreign automakers have plants here, produce most of the cars that they sell here, in fact. But Stuart, what if we do get a breakthrough, what if we do have, hey, we're just going to get rid of all of the auto tariffs between Europe and the United States? We're safe in the next three years. What if that happens, it would be incredible?

VARNEY: Huge for the markets.

MCDOWELL: Right.

VARNEY: I think the summer rally has been held back by all those negative trade headlines. It's not being pushed down so much as held back I would say. But if you get a breakthrough Wednesday, and they come out with at least a lessening of the tension, an agreement in some form or other to just maybe get rid of some tariffs, that I think would be absolutely huge, that would really set the stage for a big rally.

MCDOWELL: I think about this every morning when I get up. That is the danger of always being negative and --

VARNEY: Wait a minute, wait a minute. The first thing you think of when you wake up in the morning, is, oh, the Europeans are coming to a trade deal. I don't believe it, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: No, being positive and making sure that you don't look at everything through a negative lens because again, then you miss all the good stuff.

VARNEY: That's the whole point about the Trump presidency, isn't it? Think positive. He's winning, the economy is expanding, we've got prosperity coming at us. You know, think positive, that's why the market is up so much.

MCDOWELL: And even with some mean tweets, that's why his approval ratings are up, too. Stuart, great to see you.

VARNEY: True. Thanks, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, he starts in 10 minutes every day, 9:00 a.m. to noon. Coming up, a phone booth worthy of Superman. Details on the new office cubicle that will cost you over $8,000, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: The death toll rising in last night's mass shooting in Toronto. Cheryl Casone has the details. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Dagen, we just got an update from police. A second victim has died from the rampage, a gunman shot 14 people including a young girl in Toronto. The 29-year-old suspect's body was later found at the scene, but it's not clear at this point whether the man actually killed himself or he was shot by police. All of this happened in the Toronto neighborhood known as Greektown.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I would say I heard at least 20 shots in intervals. You know, clippings spent, reloading, clipping spent, reloading, clipping spent, that's what I heard.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well, investigators are trying to find a motive. Police say they would not rule out, at this point, terrorism.

Well, tragedy in Maryland overnight after a firefighter died while battling a massive seven alarm blaze. The unidentified firefighter, a 13-year veteran fell through the floor. Three people who were inside the house were able to get out, though, in time. The cause of the fire under investigation, but lightning could be the cause.

Well, some stunning news over the weekend at a change at the top for FiatChrysler. Long-time CEO Sergio Marchionne has been replaced. Marchionne underwent shoulder surgery three weeks ago but in those three weeks, his condition has somehow worsened. We're looking for more details. Now, Mike Manley, who runs the Jeep, SUV, and Ram truck division is the new CEO. While the stock is something to watch today, shares are actually lower in the premarket, it's down more than three percent right now. Again, stunning news over the weekend for this company.

Well, a Superman solution for workers who want more privacy, for the first time in 80 years, the Superman cubicle booth is available for purchase. It fits two people inside -- if that makes sense -- it comes with modern necessities like USB outlets and an Ethernet connection, LED lights. You're going to have to make more money than Clark Kent, though, it's actually running about $8500 per booth. And by the way, in the description it doesn't mention to actually having a phone. I don't think people use those anymore, all right.

And then, finally, there is this, we've been watching this clip over and over again this morning on the show. It appears to show a grown man stealing a foul ball from a child. Well, the Chicago Cubs saw the situation play out in real-time. They ended up giving the young boy an autographed baseball instead. But it turns out the man that everybody is criticizing had helped that boy get a foul ball earlier in the game. You can see him holding a game-used baseball next to his new autographed one, obviously. Yes. So, maybe the guy in the clip isn't as mean as we all think, and we're all beating up on him this morning. So, I wanted to, you know, give you some new details on this developing story in baseball. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Glad I didn't call him a lot of mean -- maybe.

CASONE: Yes, I think he's -- I think he's a little on a defensive.

MCDOWELL: The child deserves all the foul balls. How about that, though?

CASONE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Coming up, some final thoughts from our all-stars. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Lindsey Bell, Lee Carter, quick final thoughts. Five seconds.

SPICER: I'm glad to be here to kick off the briefing. Thanks for having me.

(LAUGHTER)

MCDOWELL: Stuart Varney, take it away, Sir.

VARNEY: I'm surprised at Sean Spicer. I thought he got more to him than that one. He had at least five seconds to spare there.

(LAUGHTER)

SPICER: I yield it to you, Stuart.

VARNEY: Well, you're a good man.

END

It's not up as much say, a Facebook, an Amazon or even a Microsoft, Microsoft is up closer to eight percent, but it's still got a really nice fat gain on in for the month. ESKANDAR: Well, you know, it's interesting that you mention Facebook , that's also going to report later on, I believe it's on Wednesday. MCDOWELL: And Amazon , later on the week. ESKANDAR: And Amazon . But ...
